awd_titl_txt: Developing Science Leaders Through Applied Learning Experiences and Reflection
awd_abstract_narration:
Austin College will fill a critical gap in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) education and to promote the national interest by producing a workforce ready for 21st century STEM jobs.  The guiding philosophy of the project is that all thoughtful and scientifically trained people should be prepared to assume leadership roles at some point in their careers.  By integrating education in five leadership behaviors--communicating ideas, problem solving, foresight and planning, collaborative work, and acting responsibly--with research and service learning, Austin College will prepare its students to be leaders and active participants in the 21st century workforce.  

The Developing Science Leaders Through Applied Learning Experiences and Reflection project will integrate leadership training directly into the STEM curriculum.  Using a framework developed as part of the STEM Teaching and Research (STAR) Leadership Program, the project will employ high-impact educational practices including providing common intellectual experiences, collaborative assignments and projects, undergraduate research opportunities and service- and community-based learning. The research component will assess whether students' leadership capabilities grow as a result of the project and will determine whether the applied learning components of the STAR Leadership Program contribute to a sense of belonging, interdependence-independence, growth versus fixed mindset, and self-efficacy in STEM. To increase the impact, the proposed research will leverage an ongoing longitudinal study, developed as part of a prior S-STEM award, which examines the impact of the leadership curriculum. The results could add to the STEM educational paradigm by demonstrating that including more holistic training in personal attributes helps students to succeed in the STEM workforce and graduate programs.

por.por_cntn:
Austin College aims to fill a critical gap in STEM education by promoting the inclusion of non-technical skills into classroom learning and providing opportunities for students to practice these skills outside of the classroom through the high-impact practices of STEM research opportunities and independently designed service-learning projects.  Intentionally instructing students in non-technical skills enhance their ability to communicate, collaborate, and act responsibly in a disciplinary context.  Focusing on the disciplinary skill sets that make for a better and more rounded scientist will be critical when engaging the broader community and promoting national interests by producing a capable workforce prepared to fill 21st century STEM jobs. 

In the course of undergraduate and graduate studies, students are focused on becoming technically proficient. Only after becoming a professional in their discipline is time found to develop the skills to lead a team, often through trial and error. A larger discussion of how scientists gain the skills to become leaders in their field has been ongoing for decades. This project integrates leadership training directly into the STEM curricula and high-impact practices, as defined by the Association of American Colleges & Universities. Building on these and other evidence-based practices, our work explores the benefits of integrated leadership training into research- and service-learning-based applied learning opportunities.  Austin College launched the STEM Teaching and Research (STAR) Leadership Program in 2013. Through the STAR Leadership Program, roughly 375 STEM students each semester benefit from STEM courses incorporating evidence-based leadership components.

This project's objective is to develop and pilot (i) a research-based applied learning opportunity and (ii) a service-learning-based applied learning opportunity that incorporates STAR Leadership Program principles.

The research component of the program assesses whether students’ leadership capabilities grow as a result of the program and determine whether the applied learning components of the STAR leadership program contribute to self-efficacy in STEM.  Self-efficacy is the perception of one’s own abilities and can be thought of as confidence that one can do something. Higher confidence is directly related to persistence, resilience, and achievement and allows students to interpret difficult situations as challenges rather than threats. 

Data generated by the program demonstrates that students have the ability to learn and enhance their self-efficacy which can be measured by a sense of belonging, their perception of being interdependent or independent, and by asking if students have a growth mindset vs. a fixed mindset.  Data collected supported our hypothesis that greater involvement in leadership training through participation in the applied learning opportunities, combined with the curricular components, predicted a greater sense of belonging, growth mindset, and self-efficacy in STEM. An additional method of assessment was the use of open-ended reflections that the students would write at the end of their projects.  The overwhelming responses seen in these reflections were about awareness. Students became aware of the interconnectedness of how what they were learning in the classroom applied to both research and the broader community of interactions they have daily.  Students often expressed that they used the tools of communication and problem solving to address interpersonal conflict or to resolve seemingly insurmountable tasks by working collaboratively with their peers, mentors, and others. Most interesting was the number of students who reported productively using the slills they had developed in ther personal lives and how it was positvly impacting their ability to be more impactful in their lives ouside of science.

The most important aspects we learned from this project are the best strategies to cultivate the non-technical skills students will need in their future STEM careers within the context of their classes and through the high-impact practices of undergraduate research and service learning.  The program impacted 11 faculty and 62 students.  Of those students 26% are still enrolled, 13% went to graduate school, 11% went to medical school and 50% joined the workforce.  Of those entering the workforce nealy half indicated that they were taking a gap year prior to continuing further education.  Additionally, Austin College received an endowment gift that will support the STAR Leadership Program, which will actively support both the curricular integration of leadership theory into STEM classes and continue the research opportunities that were piloted by this grant.
